awd_titl_txt: Supporting Science Students through Scholarships, Academic and Social Activities, and Reflective Journaling
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, this project at Joliet Junior College is designed to address the ever-increasing need in Illinois and surrounding areas for highly qualified STEM professionals. It will add to the local, regional, and national understanding of learning as it enhances student retention, performance, graduation, and peer support networks. A structured research study will be used to determine the impact of course specific tutoring, mentoring, and reflective journaling among students in STEM courses. The project will also assess and track the metacognitive skills that students use to advance their scientific thinking. Data reflecting the activities will be used to improve the program for all participants, as well as inform the academic community through conference papers and presentations at national and regional conferences. Each of these areas will be evaluated by an external evaluator using surveys, rubrics, and performance in specific courses to gather both quantitative and qualitative information about the project. Due to the demographics of the institution and the targeted recruitment of women and other underrepresented groups from both high schools and the college, the project will help to diversify the workforce.

To increase the number of academically talented students with demonstrated financial need who begin and complete a STEM program of study, the college will integrate scholarships and academic support with STEM faculty mentoring, reflective journaling, social cohorts, hands-on experiential learning through relevant research projects, and exposure to industry leaders and topics to provide scholars a pathway to success in STEM fields. Involvement in STEM classes, increased faculty mentoring geared to specific student needs, and reflective journals will encourage students to embrace the STEM community and find their own identity within it, while simultaneously learning how to mentor the next generation of scientists. Information gathered during classes, mentoring, reflective journals, student evaluations will inform the wider STEM community at the college, as well as increase awareness of student group building within the college student academic and support programs.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to increase the number of academically talented, underserved students with demonstrated financial need who begin and complete a STEM program of study.

We increased the number of students from low-income backgrounds and underrepresented groups in STEM recruited, enrolled, and progressing towards completion of a STEM major. In our program, we showed an overall retention rate of students leading to successful transfer to a four-year school of 69% of the students receiving the S-STEM scholarship. This rate was significantly higher than the 1-year retention rate of STEM students reported by the college's institutional research during the middle of our program. Institutional research reported retention of STEM students between 42-46% over 2020-2021.  

We organized support activities, including undergraduate research, as well as intensive guided pathway interventions to support student retention. We expanded the undergraduate research opportunities, especially in the summer terms. We also expanded the research opportunities to the Fall and Spring semesters as a way of increasing interest in the Summer research programs. The guided pathway interventions did not seem to affect student retention. Students made use of the guided pathways, but except for two of the students accepted into our S-STEM program, all the students stayed with their original plan of study they had coming into the program. At most, only minor changes to course enrollments were made, but none of those changes necessitated a student changing from their guided pathway.

We improved academic support through mentoring, experiential learning through a research project, outreach to students, and other high touch professional activities, as well as reflective journaling, to bring underserved students to success in the STEM fields. Our mentoring program was most successful in the years before the COVID-19 pandemic, when students in the program were more actively participating and regularly attending classes on campus. We hosted interactive sessions for S-STEM participants introducing them to various campus support services including the tutoring and writing center, the career services office, the library, and other services. One of the activities most reported by the S-STEM students to be their favorite and most memorable were the outreach events that we did at local middle schools. The S-STEM students shared with 6th grade classes their passion for the STEM fields by doing hands-on demonstrations at middle schools and being able to answer questions from 6th grade students. 

We developed strong learning community cohorts. The community aspect of our S-STEM program was clearly the strongest in the years before the COVID-19 pandemic. We were able to bring most of our S-STEM students together regularly for events and discussions about successfully navigating their college experience.  Although we maintained a sense of community with online meetings in the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic, as the students in the program transferred out to four-year universities, we lost the sense of community because new students coming into the program did not want to be in online meetings with unfamiliar students and professors. Towards the end of the S-STEM project, we regained the communal aspect with students coming into the program and becoming engaged in our planned activities.

Joliet Junior College’s S-STEM Program enhanced student retention, performance, breadth of understanding, and student peer support networks as well as enhanced the understanding of course specific tutoring, mentoring, and reflective journaling among students in STEM courses at JJC. The project assessed and tracked students' metacognitive skills to advance their scientific thinking.

This project benefited local, regional, and national understanding of learning dynamics. This S-STEM Program at JJC positively affected students, the College, and understanding of the learning process. The successes and deficiencies of this program can be used to improve the program for future participants, as well as informing the academic community through conference papers and presentations at national and regional conferences. Involvement in their STEM classes, increased faculty mentoring, and reflective journals encouraged students to embrace the STEM community and find their own identity within it, while simultaneously showing them how to mentor the next generation of scientists. Information gathered during classes, mentoring, reflective journals, and during student evaluation of the program have impacted the wider STEM community at JJC, as well as increasing awareness of student group building within the college's student academic and support programs. Improving the quality and number of STEM graduates through the S-STEM program at JJC helps fill the need of more qualified STEM professionals in the state of Illinois and the nation.


Last Modified: 04/30/2024
Modified by: Andrew Morrison
